name: 2-chloro-6-nitro-4-(trifluoromethyl)aniline
Reason: 2-chloro-6-nitro-4-(trifluoromethyl)aniline has a basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The chlorine atom increases the molecular weight and electronegativity, which generally raises the melting point. The nitro group also increases the electronegativity and introduces a dipole moment, further increasing the melting point. The trifluoromethyl group is a polar functional group that can participate in hydrogen bonding, which can lower the melting point. The overall effect of these functional groups is a complex interplay of increasing and decreasing factors, which we will consider individually and then combine to predict the melting point of 2-chloro-6-nitro-4-(trifluoromethyl)aniline.
